review_title: Wonderful Nonprofit That Has Some Kinks
pros: Special Olympics Texas (SOTX) is a wonderful nonprofit, doing really great things in communities and for athletes to push inclusivity and opportunities for those with intellectual disabilities (ID). The work/life balance is excellent, as long as you show that you get your work done in an efficient and time-sensitive manner. Lots of great vacation time and benefits are given, not typical for a nonprofit. Pay is not outstanding, but good for a nonprofit. Management can be wonderful if you have the same work style as your manager. SOTX pushes being a go-getter and thinking outside the box, while also listening carefully to what initiative the President wants to push. SOTX has gone through a lot of growing pains in the past 5 years with a new President and staff turnaround, but it's now really narrowed in on the overall goal and has fiscally come a long way. Overall, SOTX values the athletes and thebottom line is to make their experience positive.
cons: As an employee, your experience will vary depending on your manager, your location, and your capability towards being independently driven in your role. I have seen a lot of people let go for not understanding what is expected of them and for not taking initiative independently. There are certain idiosyncrasies within the culture, which you don't fully understand until you are employed there for some time. Communication can be a challenge until you learn what way works best for each employee or manager (email, text, phone), as well as the organization of duties. Systems have begun to manifest but there is still some work to be done.

pros: The mission of Special Olympics is incredible and the opportunity to meet and work with so many incredible athletes is the best part of the job. You also get the sense the most people working there do it for the mission and are involved in their personal lives as well. The partnerships with professional sports teams also allows some really great opportunities for athletes and staff. It's a very supportive team, very friendly and a great group to work with.
cons: There is very little communication or organization between departments. Each department does what's best for their department and collaboration comes second. There is also no explanation for policies or procedures. Raises and the idea of promotions are all secretive and there is no set standard for when or how someone gets promoted. Higher ups aren't always aware of the work that those below them are doing and then the work goes unnoticed the the employees doing the work don't get rewarded justly.

review_title: SOA is a great place to make a difference and learn some skills that will help you take the next step in your career.
pros: Its a great way to work for an organization that is doing something amazing in the community.  Knowing that you are making a difference in the lives of those with intellectual disabilities, as well as those who support them, has been great and makes it easy to stay motivated during times when the work seems tedious.  It is a small group working environment, which is nice because you form some strong relationships.  There is also opportunity for work at the national and international levels through committees and working groups, along with conferences.  For a sport organization, it is nice because there are 15 official sport to provide variety in projects.
cons: Being a not-for-profit organization and a sport organizations has its benefits, but also its drawbacks.  The amount of work required by the employees outstrips the hours and effort that is put into the job.  it also serves to split the attention of the staff and their projects; are we doing the right thing for sport or the right things for the athletes?  Most times this is not an issue, but sometimes you have to settle, which is unsatisfying.  Also, for some of the work required on the executive management side, you will be underpaid based on what you are providing.  If this was for profit, you could expect to make at least 20% more.

pros: The mission of this organization is incredible. Working events are truly amazing and the best part of the job. I met people and had experiences that I will truly never forget and changed my life for the better.
cons:
They have no respect for their employees and certainly don't value them. Raises for the folks who actually ran the programs where non-existent, but yet the folks at the top (CEO, CFO, VPs) had yearly raises built in-to their contracts. So the CEO would stand in front of the room and tell you he was sorry that people where getting raises and he wishes their was something he could do all while taking his yearly raise.  

The balance between program staff and development staff was way off. I understand money is needed to run the organization, but the people who actually did the true mission of the organization where far out number and well underpaid. 

Lastly, the work life balance was terrible! If you enjoy having a life, on the nights and weekends, this isn't the place for you. 50-60 hour weeks were the norm and flextime did exist but you would get push back when trying to take it.

job_title: Senior Operations Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: nice people that work there and they are professional
cons: the pay is pay, and having to deal with volunteers

pros: Everyone's very nice and respectful.
cons: No cons. Everyone got along very well.

pros: Team driven and culture is fun to be around
cons: Instability/lower salary than market demand

job_title: Director of Special Events in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Great Organazation to work with. Love what they do
cons: Nothing. Overall a great place to work

review_title: Great brand, great mission, but not enough to make up for poor management and culture
pros: Mission of inclusion is important and relevant. Global reach and great brand recognition (albeit not complete for what the organization truly delivers - no it is not the ParaOlympics and it is not just about Games).   Truly Incredible athletes, families and supporters.
cons: Limited opportunity for growth. Workload is unevenly distributed  - some colleagues are overwhelmingly busy while others are not.  Management plays favorites and senior roles go to inexperienced managers who can not effectively lead teams.  Over performers are rarely recognized. Work/life balance is non existent.  Unfriendly environment at times, which is not in line with their mission of acceptance and inclusion.   Strong focus on bringing in money at any cost.

pros: Special Olympics Illinois is a great place to work. The people here are friendly and dedicated to their job. The organization is well-run and has very focused goals that it consistently achieves year after year. It has remained financially sound during a difficult recession. You also feel proud to work here knowing that you are working for a good cause to help disadvantaged members of society to have a happier and healthier life.
cons: The downsides of the job are that there isn't much room for promotion or advancement as it is a rather small organization that is scattered in different areas of the state and there are only a few levels of job title. It is also hard to move up as there is so much difference in experience and education needed between the different jobs that one doesn't readily lead to another. The other downside is that resources and access are not always shared as they should be.

review_title: If you want to be treated like a slave...intern here.
pros: Great cause. Met a lot of great vendors/talent. Some of the work was fun and I learned a little bit.
cons: One of the gals I trained under was a real "you know what"...some of the guys that worked as freelance for the company were drinking on the job and using drugs. Most of the employees seemed knowledgeable of their own jobs and just muttered through it. Waited till last minute to do things. I received a  whooping 300 check at the end of my 3 month internship and after taxes got 280!! Not worth it for all they had me doing...running errands in my car, making copies, stuffing envelopes, sorting through a warehouse, lifting and carrying heavy boxes, calling vendors on my personal phone so they're returning calls all hours for days after, the computers there were horrible and I couldn't hardly get any work even done!!!!!

pros: Enjoyed working with the athletes, families and volunteers within the organization!
cons: This organization is a horrible mess!  It's not run like a business should be.  Leadership bullies employees and even volunteers to get what they want- bring in more money!!!  Sure we have millions in the bank but if over-worked, underpaid, untrained staff and volunteers do not bring in the big bucks (in small towns where the organization has a bad reputation for over 20 years)- off with their head! Yes, even volunteers are "fired"   I am an idealist and want to help and do the right thing, which is why I worked in non-profit but seeing how this politically and money-driven NPO works was absolutely devastating and made me want to switch careers b/c I will not raise money for a corrupt organization that treats their faithful followers this way.

pros: The people who work at SOI are truly extraordinary. Everyone goes above and beyond and I would say the majority of people put the athletes first. The environment is supportive and ideas from anyone are considered.
cons: The discrepancies between salaries is astounding. There are "blocks" of position titles which don't make sense. A "manager" on one team could be making $40k, while a manager on another team is making $70k. If there is no measurable difference in pay with position titles, why even have them in the first place? There are people who have been at SO for decades who hold the organization back from moving forward into new spaces with new ideas. The lower level working staff is brilliant and has fresh takes on things, listen to them!

review_title: A position with Special Olympics gave me that feel good all over feeling everyday.
job_title: Area Support Coordinator in Tucson, AZ
pros: Working with individuals with special needs puts life into perspective. These athletes show a special outlook on life and what is really important in life. Seeing the excitement when one of the athletes achieves a goal or competes in a competition lets me know what is really important in life.
cons: There are several issues mainly dealing with non-profit companies. The biggest is funding and accessing sources for funding both the development and competition aspects of Special Olympics.

review_title: Interned at SOTX a few summers and had a great experience!
pros: This is a great starting experience and the company works for a great cause if you want to get into the non-profit or NGO industry. The staff and my co-workers at the SOTX Austin HQ were very friendly and respectful. You will even get to make connections with the higher ups and the CEO. The pay was pretty good for an internship and I think overall you will learn a lot about this industry and you will get to help people with intellectual disabilities and learn that they are no different from you and I!
cons: Not a lot of growth or leadership opportunities. There are some tedious manual labor activities you will need to complete such as data entry, but it is understandable that you will have to do these tasks even as an employee. I wish there were more hands on opportunities to work with the actual athletes!

job_title: Graphic Designer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people, welcoming environment, wonderful and inclusive experiences. Management, coworkers and athletes were all wonderful people to work and collaborate with. It was a very loving environment.
cons: They don't know what to do with designers...we were asked to design a range of in-house documents that circulated just to other departments in the company as busy work. The actual work we thought we would be doing was being done at an outside advertising agency as well as with a partnership with a local college, leaving us very little to contribute. When we did have projects, people did not understand our process and would rush us as there were only 2 designers including myself on staff. We would regularly not have much to do, so although everyone was wonderful, the work was very dry.

review_title: Special Olympics Maryland- great cause, unprofessional culture.
pros: Great mission, met awesome people and made great relationships with athletes and families. Really connects you with the community. small office environment, flexible work hours, relaxed dress code,  tenured staff who knows a lot about the organization.
cons: Disconnect between CEO’s vision and staff’s expertise and beliefs in what is achievable. Lacking many of the basic HR standards an organization needs to function. Inconsistent performance standards and nothing driving accountability. Little to no coaching provided. Priority placed on optics of serving the mission rather than being able to show results and progress through data. Lack of diversity across staff - group think very prevalent.

pros: Working for the athletes is very rewarding, seeing the greatness that "disabled" people can bribng to this world is fantastic.
cons: There is never enough money. We grow revenue at 5% per year in a down economy and still we hear about how we are not doing a good job at revenue creation. The system is set up for the organization to be very grassroots, but they want the organization to perforn at a national organization level. Organization needs some clarity about what they are and what their expectations for the volunteer supporters are...

pros: The athletes are great!  They have a blast with the events that are put on by the senior staff.
cons:
Management doesn't know what they're doing; lack of communication between management and top volunteers; when the volunteers wanted to do something, management would say no, but when management wanted to do something, volunteers would say no.

it's all about politics working here. 

They don't care about you at all by any means as they're all self-centered.  On the surface, they act like they care about their employees, but they really don't.

When I was interviewed, they told me that the previous person in my position was there for 5+ years which was a lie.  The previous Program Director was only there for about 3 months.

pros: Overall mission is great as are the atheletes.
cons:
Directionless leadership, wherever the boss man decides to focus on tomorrow,the entire organization has to pivot and drop what they are doing to support his latest folly.
SVPs who clearly have no experience doing their job and take joy in creating division and animosity among the teams.
Lack of racial diversity in top and mid level leadership. Some SVPs try to work remotely from far away cities ,moonlighting with other lucrative roles and have no sense of what is going on at HQ.
General rude, unprofessional, unsupportive environment  created by certain SVP'sand their clique of WASPs.
Complaints to HR seem to fall on deaf ears.
Some hints of race related favoritism for promotions and in work assignments.
A CEO who does not lead effectively because she works in the shadow of the  boss man.

pros:
We have a great mission that speaks to people around the world. 
Getting to meet the athletes and contribute to their welfare through health events, games, and more!
HR does a good job working with Lions Club to do fundraisers/office events. 
Great coworkers! The new people are the best!
Giving job opportunities within.
The hiring process is fantastic as well - very all inclusive.
cons:
Office politics is very much alive... and kills. But this is only with the people who have been here too long. 
The company can't keep a CEO. One disagreement with the Chairman and you're out. 
Non-profit salary and budgets.
Disconnect with upper management and rest of staff.

review_title: Awesome Mission, Tough Work Place Environment
pros:
Great place to volunteer and they help an extraordinary group of human beings. 
 A lot of the staff care about their job and put forth an amazing amount of effort.
cons:
I've seen it not be a great work environment for some of the staff. Not organized or professional internally. 
Wouldn't recommend as an entry-level job. They expect you to have the knowledge of someone who has been working for 10+ years just starting out.

pros: The brand recognition opens doors. It is possible every day to create impact in real lives, on a massive scale, all over the world. The opportunity for growth can be tremendous. If travel is your thing, there is plenty of opportunity for that, including internationally.
cons: It is a nonprofit and resources are always lean. Opportunities for advancement are stronger in some parts of the organization than others. Work-life balance isn't the point of working at Special Olympics. It is a mission-driven organization and the people who succeed there are those who bring their energy, creativity, and brains to their work during weekdays, evenings, and weekends. It's not 24/7 all the time. But sometimes it is all-in (e.g. as major events approach)

pros: The Mission - the athletes are what make you come into work. They are welcoming and very much make you feel like family. They make it worthwhile.
cons:
Toxic.Workplace. 

I found the upper level management to be unrealistic and filled with in-fighting and backstabbing. There was no real discussion about the reason for setting certain goals or if a goal was even achievable. When asked for feedback, the upper level management would obfuscate or outright reject it. This seeped down to make the workplace politics impossible to deal with and a detriment to the ability to get things done. SO will never move mainstream until new management and management goals are in place. They can't keep young, mid-level staff to help them grow.

pros:
Demanding. When you work in recruitment you are providing a service to candidates and clients. This means that if you say you’ll do something you need to do it and sometimes this may mean that you’ll end up staying late after work or even getting into the office early. It’s those that go the extra mile that reap the rewards.
Not for the faint hearted. Recruitment can be a tough old business, some days you’ll feel like everything you touch turns to gold, on others you’ll feel like it’s falling apart. Every day is a new day and with that comes new opportunities and challenges, so you need to be resilient.
All about people. Your business is people. Whether you’re selling a client to a candidate or a candidate to a client, your product and your business is people. This means you can’t just have good communication skills, you need excellent communication skills. Recruitment is about fulfilling needs, managing expectations and providing an add-value service.
Fast paced. You’re in the middle of a phone call or writing an email when a colleague shouts “Job on!” You drop everything in an instant and get on the phone briefing candidates on your new role, making sure that every second counts. If your team aren’t on the phone calling and briefing candidates you could lose that candidate to another agency which could mean losing out on a fee. It’s a flash of adrenaline, it’s excitement, it’s fast paced and definitely not a role for a slow coach.
cons: lacing your first candidate or even your hundredth, this industry is hugely satisfying. Working through the entire recruitment process from sourcing a candidate to briefing them on a job and coaching them through the interview process to the offer stage, it’s a job that you can see the benefits of from the beginning. Knowing that you’ve not only made a great fee, but have made a difference to someone’s work team and career makes this job really worth it.

review_title: Lots of freedom to plan my day because there is no official office.  Can ask lots of questions and get ideas.
pros: Can follow your own leads and work flexible hours.  Great management attitude and leadership coming from the mainland office.
cons: Hard to read some people in the group.  There is a conflict in the group's dynamics of who is giving the orders because there are so many volunteers.

pros: The mission. It's all worth it for the athletes. It's great being advocates on their behalf. Some of the volunteers are awesome and dedicate their lives to this
cons: The Schenectady office. So called VP and COO of NY. Both out of their leagues. One has been around for 30 years and the other is not sophisticated or savvy enough to hold her position. Long time volunteers/parents need to move on. So much entitlement and expectations. They are poison to the organization.

pros: Great mission.  Wonderful people. The name Special Olympics opens doors and most people are happy to talk to you. Working with the athletes and their families is a true pleasure.
cons: Long hours.  Almost every weekend was taken up with some fundraiser or athletic competition. Very little money. I had to struggle to make ends meet.

review_title: Working with Special Olympics has been one of the most rewarding things I have ever done. The athletes are great!
job_title: Retail Store Management in Lodi, CA
pros: Working with Special Olympics athletes helps me by keeping me grounded while also affording me the opportunity to work alongside the athletes
cons: Every community of any significant size should participate in Special Olympics. The event coordinators, athletes and their families are very special people.

review_title: As with ay job, we have our share of frustrations, but overall it is a good job with adequate compensation.
pros: Helping individuals with intellectual disabilities develop self esteem as they learn to become not just good athletes but viable members of their communities.
cons: Communication between personnel in the Chapter Office and field staff lacks consistency which oten leaves the Area offices trying to meet management directed goals without clear direction.

review_title: Great organization, needs more HR support
pros: People are passionate about the mission. Lots of opportunities to explore disability in different cultural contexts. Tackling entrenched, endemic stigma is challenging, intellectually stimulating, and rewarding. People who work there are very smart and driven.
cons: Not a lot of effort put into the work culture. As with any nonprofit, funding constraints can cause challenges.

pros: Special Olympics is an amazing organization with a great mission. As an employee there are many opportunities to meet and get to know Special Olympics athletes. It is truly rewarding to see how much joy they get from participating in competitions and trainings.
cons: The pay is very low. During hard financial times there were cuts in sports programs which was very difficult to witness because it directly affected the athletes. There weren't many opportunities for promotions because the organization is very small.

pros: The work performed was for a great cause and I met many wonderful people. I enjoyed working with an organization that was international and offered wonderful meaningful opportunities to persons with disabilities.
cons: There was a time when management decided to combine departments in order to cut cost and many employees lost their job.

review_title: Fun and exciting with growing pains
pros: People are pasionate about Special Olympics and their belief in the mission shows through their work ethic.
cons: Special Olympics is going through growing pains.  It's basically a "family" run business trying to engage and grow in a global environment.

pros: Great organization with a worthwhile mission, which emphasizes putting the Athletes first.
cons: They lack innovation on many fronts. A few ppl in the senior leadership team are unqualified for their positions and are/were promoted due to seniority rather than bringing in fresh talent. They've even had challenges hanging onto a CEO. FYI, Sargent Shriver passed away a few years ago.

job_title: Senior Development Director in Houston, TX
pros: Special Olympics in itself is a wonderful organization and cause. The cause is easy to sell and the athlete involvement motivates
cons: Over Worked, understaffed.  Upper Management not professional.  Upper development management does not have skills required to perform job

pros: The athletes and volunteers make the job worth it. Mission of the organization is  great and if you can live the mission it is a life changing organization
cons: They do not value their employees, if not a VP expect to make 1/2 to 1/3 of management. Under appreciate volunteers and have come to expect so much out of their volunteers

pros: The employees are all very nice and welcoming to new employees and with everyone they interact with.  The supervisors are understanding of personal circumstances that come up from time to time.  Hours can also be slightly flexible during the day, as long as you get the work done that needs to get done.  The environment is fun and casual.
cons: It can sometimes be disorganized and chaotic.

job_title: Marketing and Development Intern in Columbus, OH
pros:
Great experience because you are actually allocated responsibility.
Small, intimate office.
Staff is very friendly and passionate.
cons: Office can be very quiet at times. Other than that I have difficulty finding many other cons. Some people do great in that environment.

pros:
- passionate employees
- great mission and vision for the company, feel-good atmosphere for helping people with intellectual disabilities 
- good benefits plan, lots of vacation and lieu time (but that is because you'll be working weekends)
- parking easy
cons:
- standard not-for-profit environment; so not a lot of lavish 'perks'
- if you do not drive and do not live on a good bus line, transit isn't great

review_title: Changes to leadership have resulted in major turnover
pros:
Amazing mission and inspiring athletes 
Good benefits
Flexible hours/schedule
cons:
Shifting values from athletes to fundraising/financial gain
Lack of communication from management
Rapid changing of ideas and programs with no consultation or input 
No clarity on job duties or delegation of responsibilities 
Did not feel supported by management nor given fair promotional opportunities

pros: Working with athletes, good health benefits, flexible PTO and time off for over-time hours.
cons: Pay is moderate, management is poor, communication needs improvement throughout the organization.

pros: The job is really inspirational; you get to work with great people with phenomenal attitudes towards their challenges and obstacles. Teaches you a lot about yourself and your own view on life.
cons: It could be a challenge if you aren't a patient person or aren't used to working with those with special needs. Personally neither of these things deterred me and are well worth the experience.

pros: Some of the employees are truly talented and wonderful people who want to make a difference in the world.
cons:
There are some truly appalling things that happen at this company: corruption, egos, bad management, and a thick, oppressive bureaucracy. 

The worst part for me was the immense disappointment I felt as I discovered the reality of the organization.

pros: Working with that athletes, planning and attending events around the province, get to visit areas around the country, work closely with experts from various sport disciplines
cons: No set structure in place, not much growth opportunities, no set structure in place to know how you will rise in the company, small raises

pros:
It's all about serving the athletes.
Great CEO with an always-open door policy.
Decent medical benefits.
cons:
Very little room for moving up in the organization. 
Large pay gap between management and directors.
Slow to progress with changing technology.

pros: Great cause, pretty flexible schedule during down time.
cons: You have to have a passion for what you are doing.  There are many longs hours, nights, weekends and travel.  I love what I do so it is not a problem for me.

pros: Great organization, fun coming to work, love the mission
cons: Poor leadership, horrible pay, HIGH turnover, no transparency, or consistency, no room for growth.

pros: worked as a development intern and loved having a tremendous amount of community support and small staff gave personal and helpful support.
cons: internship was unpaid which was expected but to some it could be hard to adapt to

pros: Unbelievable friendships that you make with athlete, partners, and volunteers out in the community
cons: Louisiana's  top management is horrendous. President does not have ability to manage staff. Not a lot of freedom to be creative, or help better a program. Don't get paid for the amount of extraordinary hours you put in.

review_title: self satisfaction.challenge to accept the reality.spread the knowledge gained.
pros: meet people,enjoy working,experience at all different levels.make these special abled feel proud of their coaches,their joyful look.
cons: Only advanteges of working right from rootlevel to limelite level.Thanks for making us feel special.

review_title: I was a coach and I enjoyed being one immensely.
pros: Working with people who had such  unique outlook on life and didn't let a whole lot get them down.
cons: The biggest issue is always worrying about funding and making sure we could provide the best available training with the amount we had to work with.

job_title: Development and Events in Boston, MA
pros:
Well-known organization and brand doing a lot of good
Decent pay for non-profit work
Great co-workers
cons:
Working weekends and not getting correct comp. time
No room for growth, upper management plays favorites
No educational incentives or grants for continuing education

pros:
-opportunity to try lots of new things/wear different hats
-flexibility in schedule
-more casual work environment
-learn to delegate tasks and manage volunteers (all departments of organization utilize volunteers)
cons:
-limited upward mobility/room to grow
-always so much to do, too little time (common nature of a nonprofit)
-limited professional training 
-work/life balance
-frequently required to drive to various locations

pros: Good Mission and passionate people.  Serving such a special population is very rewarding.  Opportunity to travel and be involved in global events.
cons: The work-life balance can be challenging.  Most positions require long hours and fair amounts of travel.  The pay can be on the lower side.

pros:
Very welcoming, family atomosphere.
Granted freedom but also given direction when necessary.
Very rewarding and fun work.
Working with the athletes was fun and I gained some great experience.
Overall a wonderful organization!
cons: Sometimes given menial tasks but they needed to get done and was gladly willing to help

review_title: Doesn't invest in employees or provide positive work culture
pros: Incredible mission and programs, dynamic growth and partnerships
cons: Doesn't offer professional development, focuses too much time and resources on non-mission related events

pros: Exposure to programs across the world - able to work on a variety of projects and with diverse people. Gaining experience with contracts, event planning, and health data.
cons: Administrative job is restricting you to work on admin duties, with only limited exposure to actual program materials and health related work.

pros: The mission is amazing and truly inspiring you often find yourself saying this is why I do this.
cons: Long hours and disorganized. No one shares the valuable information and everything is very last minute.

job_title: Administration Coordinator in Athens, Athens, Attica
pros: personal growth, getting involved with the athletes with mental disability.
cons:
Need to be treated more professional dealing with the organization of the games.

Be more clear concerning rules and regulations of every sport and in general.

review_title: Team leader with people and financial oversight authority
pros: Great mission helping the intellectually disabled across Iowa
cons: Not innovative, closed mindset, caught in the way "we've always done it."

review_title: Great Mission, but poor leadership and management
pros: The Mission and athletes.
cons:
The problem with working with SO is the mission is great and they give students jobs after college, but under-pay you and over work you with no promotion in the company. 
Upper-management WILL NOT listen to you, your concerns, or issues... you will be fired rather than heard.

pros: New leadership may turn things around. Good mission. Enjoyable events. Flexible work hours and work from home. Little to no "micro management"
cons: Pay. Lots of evenings and weekends required. Uneven funding stream means layoffs are around every corner. No strategic plan nor clear directions.

pros: Working with Great people and working for a great cause. The environment is wonderful and welcoming and a postive atmosphere
cons: At times it is frustrating because it is a non profit organization, and it is hard to get funding or raise enough money.

pros: Working  there is very rewarding, the athletes that you serve are amazing.  good staff, good benefits. Flexible hours and travel.
cons: little opportunity for promotion or salary increase.

pros: The organization does ground breaking work. The headquarters is amazing at keeping their employees interest at heart. They always strive for excellence and have a very long vision to succeed.
cons: I havent noticed any in my time there.

review_title: Noble intentions, great families, poor management
pros: The work that is accomplished is amazing, and the athletes and families are delightful to serve.
cons: Management plays favorites. Rules are different if you are liked or are a favorite.

job_title: Director, Corporate Development in Pleasant Hill, CA
pros: Building fantastic partnerships with Corporate Social Responsibility, Marketing, Human Resources and Leadership. Involved Special Olympics Athletes for Lunch & Learns.
cons: Invest in Marketing collateral, digital talking points, social media content, and data mining Coaches / Families for referrals to potential corporate partners.

pros: It is a great movement towards helping a worthy population!
cons: Upper management does not value deadlines, which makes decision-making at a lower level very difficult.

pros: The experience was great because cause marketing serves such great purpose.
cons: There are no cons that I wish to share. This was a freelance post for me.

review_title: This organization provides tremendous opportunity to all its employees. it feels satisfying to work for a cause.
pros: Good Learning, More responsibilities, Good environment, Open to opportunities.
cons: None.. Only people outside need to be more sensitive for the person with intellectual disability.

pros: Cool, international coworkers that are on a mission to help improve the world.
cons: Unclear management structure that is difficult to navigate.

pros: Great place to do meaningful and enjoyable work with like minded event management people
cons: It was only a temporary gig and will be held somewhere different in 4 years.

review_title: Great place to work if you can brave the politics
pros:
Very fulfilling career
travel opportunities
great future prospects
cons:
way too much politics
low compensation
no work life balance
lack of organization and standardized practices

job_title: Medical Hub Manager in Sierra Madre, CA
pros: Good people doing good things.  Everyone works very hard to do a good job so that the athletes receive the most from their experience.
cons: No cons, but prepare to work hard and for long hours

review_title: Great for job seekers that love community outreach  but not tech savvy job seekers.
pros: Great cause, great volunteers, community outreach.
cons: Outdated Software that if updated would save money and time.

pros: Great mission, objectives, and families.
cons: Amount of hours you put in is pretty horrendous. In my experience, management and culture was very disorganised, unprofessional, and aggressive.

pros: good people, good mission, athletes are the best!
cons: no gratitude for employees putting in so much work at the big events, organization is run very much from the top with little regard for those at the bottom

pros: Great mission! How can you not love an organization that highlights the good of folks with ID.
cons: Unorganized! Hard to get things accomplished.

job_title: Human Resources Benefits Administrator in Sandyford
pros: It was a great organization to work for and a wonderful cause to be apart of to help bring awareness to the World.
cons: There were no cons to working for this organization.

review_title: Hard work leads to rewarding events and outcomes with the athletes.
job_title: Sport Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: All your hard work benefits the athletes, excellent coworkers, everybody has the same mission
cons: Some leadership conflicts with lower level employees,

pros: Good team, amazing athletes, stressful but great place to work
cons: Staff is competitive and all out for themselves, disorganized

pros: Decent salary for a non-profit, general public support for the mission
cons: Technologically ancient, old guard crowd resistant to change, poor training

pros: Amazing organization servicing a talented and great population of angels on earth.
cons: Minimal tangible support provided outside core team.

pros: Interesting work, varied, travel, great colleagues.  Rewarding work, every day is different.
cons: Limited upward mobility and opportunities outside role.

pros: Excellent culture and you really feel as though you are playing an integral part in the company's mission.
cons: Pay is not great, but in line with other non-profits.

pros: Fantastic organisation. Hard work but rewarding with good work life balance. Treats employees fairly.
cons: Some department manager micro manage their staff

review_title: Working at Special Olympics Alberta is a rewarding and life-changing experience.
pros: The athletes, the inspiration, the knowledge that we are making a difference.
cons: None to share at this time.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Long Beach, CA
pros: Culture, mission, athlete interaction, CEO is amazing, work is rewarding, staff is very positive.
cons: Nothing I can think of. I was very happily employed.

pros: Great organization working toward a great cause.  Solid support from the city and partners
cons: Communication between departments could be significantly improved

pros: It was something to put on the resume.
cons: It was a lot of data entry and clerical work. I didn't really get to do anything based on my major.

pros: Trrating employeers like human! Really attentive stuff and in any life case ou can rey at your boss!
cons: Didn't notice something special.

pros:
- great benefits

cons: Sometimes you may need to work long hours around special events

review_title: A good place to work, with clear set goals
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Abu Dhabi, Abu Dhabi
pros: Challenging, great atmosphere, friendly people.

review_title: A very good experience if you like non profits!
pros: Everyone is very nice and willing to help to succeed.
cons: Contacting everyone was a bit of a hassle

pros: Great mission, great people. Lots of work and limited resources allow you to expand your role and responsibilities rapidly
cons: Lot of disconnection internally.

pros: Awesome people. Really love their work.
cons: None really. I had a great time volunteering.

pros: Going to Special Olympics can turn a bad day into a great one!

Travel experience
Social services
Leave bonus

Small office
Not too interesting work environment

pros: The organization is really mission focused and dedicated. They also care for you as a person.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement

review_title: Amazing people who really make a difference
pros: Great atmosphere with very positive people ready to make a difference
cons: Varying hours made things a bit unsteady

pros: Great experience. Wonderful people to work with.
cons: No significant downsides. Pretty rapid project turn around but still manageable

pros: the salary was enough and we get it in time
cons: i was  married and so l fallow my family

pros: Great people who care about the company values, provide good advice, and are friendly.

cons: Funding challenges necessitated constant changes and adjustments to plans

pros: Awesome people, half days on Friday, good support from boss

pros: Amazing mission to join and very fast-paced work environment

pros: The athletes and important, urgent work with global reach.

pros: Great staff, in it for the athletes

pros: You are making a difference in lives
cons: It is a lot if work for not much pay

pros: rewarding, great people, contributing to the community

pros: Great mandate. Amazing staff. Awesome athletes and coaches.

pros: Very wholesome and fun experience altogether.

pros: great organization and the volunteers and athletes are fantastic

pros: Great family atmosphere and everyone is willing to help
